_header: He is wise and well taught / that bears a horn and blows it not
Note: For these lines used as burden see 882.
_description: Precepts against boasting — a single couplet translating ‘doctus portare nonit cornu neque flare’, which follows

BodLauMis108.Transcription:
[ ]e þe wise and wel i tauȝtcan bere an horne & blow it
                    nouȝt

BodRawD328.Transcription:
He ys wyse and wel y taȝthþat beryth a horne & blow hym
                    noȝth
BodRawD328.Note:
Translating, ‘Doctus portare qui sit cornu neque
                    flare’, which follows; English portion all written on one
                    line.
BodRawD328.Editions:
Meech,  Sanford Brown. 
             “A Collection of Proverbs in Rawlinson MS D 328.” 
             Modern Philology
         38 (1940-41): 113-32: 121.

RylandsLat394.Transcription:
He is wyse & well tawȝtþat berys ahorne and blowes it
                    nowȝt
RylandsLat394.Editions:
Pantin,  William A. 
             “A Medieval Collection of Latin and English Proverbs…from Rylands
                Latin MS. 394.” 
             Bulletin of the John Rylands Library
         14 (1930): 81-114: 93.
